awd_titl_txt: Optimal Shrinkage Estimation for Heteroscedastic Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Shrinkage estimators are powerful statistical methods that have profound impact in scientific and engineering applications. They provide efficient tools to pool information from related populations for simultaneous inference -- the data on each population alone often do not lead to the most effective estimation, but by pooling information from the related populations together one can often obtain more accurate estimates for each individual population. Examples of the applications of shrinkage estimators include the analysis of healthcare systems (quality of hospital services, etc.), the analysis of education programs (the effectiveness of teaching programs), the assessment of medical treatments (pooling information from multiple studies or clinical trials), the ranking of multiple genes on their association with diseases, and the comparison of multiple manufacturing processes. This research project will investigate shrinkage estimations in the context of heterogeneous data, aiming to identify optimal ways to conduct shrinkage estimation in various settings.

This research project studies and identifies risk-optimal shrinkage estimators under parametric as well as semi-parametric settings for heteroscedastic data. In addition to thorough theoretical investigation, the project includes comprehensive numerical studies and real applications. The research topics include the investigation of optimal shrinkage estimators for heteroscedastic data from non-Gaussian exponential families; the investigation of optimal shrinkage estimators for heteroscedastic data from location-scale families; and the investigation of optimal shrinkage estimators for heteroscedastic data from linear regression models. The research aims to advance the theoretical understanding of shrinkage estimators and also provide powerful techniques for the analysis of data in medical, natural and social sciences, and engineering.

por.por_cntn:
The simultaneous inference/estimation of multiple parameters for a collection of subpopulations has generated broad interest from statisticians ever since the 1950s. Most research focused on the homogeneous case, i.e., assuming the subpopulations have homogeneous characteristics. But in practice, one often encounters heterogeneous (e.g., unequal variance) data in real applications; for example, the sample sizes for different groups are not all equal. It is natural to ask for the optimal shrinkage estimator when one needs to apply shrinkage estimators to real heterogeneous data. Our methodology and the corresponding theoretical results significantly advance our understanding of shrinkage estimators for heterogeneous data (including linear models). We not only identified competitive parametric and semi-parametric shrinkage estimators, but also rigorously proved that they are (asymptotically) optimal. In other words, practitioners can simply use our estimators with the assurance that they are (risk) optimal.

As the inference of multiple parameters for a collection of subpopulations has been widely applied in many scientific and engineering problems, our methods and the statistical theory have far-reaching impact. They can be directly applied by researchers from various scientific fields for analyzing real data. The application of our method to real-world problems leads to exciting results.

Xie, Kou and Brown (2016, Annals of Statistics, 44, 564-597) identified the optimal shrinkage estimators for heterogeneous non-Gaussian families and rigorously established that the resulting shrinkage estimators are asymptotically optimal in that no other shrinkage estimators can have smaller asymptotic risk. Kou and Yang (2016) formulated two different hierarchical models of linear regression and identified the optimal shrinkage estimators in each case.

Yang, Santillana and Kou (2015, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 112, 14473-14478) applied our method to combine information from Google's internet search data and historical flu activity (recorded by the CDC) for flu forecasting. The method has significantly improved the existing flu forecasting methods. As a consequence it has received media coverage, including Ars Technica, Harvard Gazette, Forschung aktuell (the daily German science magazine) among others. Yang, Santillana, Brownstein, Gray, Richardson and Kou (2017, BMC Infectious Diseases, 17, 332) applied our method to combine information from electronic health records, Google's internet search data and historical influenza activity (recorded by the CDC) for influenza forecasting. The new shrinkage method is able to significantly improve the forecasting accuracy of influenza occurrence over existing methods. Ning, Yang and Kou (2019, Scientific Reports, 9, 5238) applied our method to estimate influenza activities at the US regional level (as opposed to the national level); the method significantly outperformed the existing ones.

Yang, Kou, et al. (2017, PLOS Computational Biology, 13, e1005607) introduced new method to use Internet search data and historical dengue fever case counts to predict dengue fever occurrences in five tropical/sub-tropical countries/states: Brazil, Mexico, Thailand, Singapore and Taiwan. As the method gave accurate prediction, the paper received media coverage, including CNN, Science Daily, Eurekalert!, PLOS Research News, Healio and Deutsches Arzteblatt (in German) among others.

Chen, Shen, Shan and Kou (2016, Journal of American Statistical Association, 111, 951-966) introduced a new hierarchical Bayes model framework to simultaneously analyze multiple (i.e., hundreds of) heterogeneous data trajectories from single-molecule experiments. The proposed method allowed the aggregation of information from multiple heterogeneous experimental data trajectories for much sharper inference; as a consequence, our proposed method is able to significantly improve the estimation accuracy compared to the conventional way of analyzing one data trajectory at a time. 

Wong, Liu and Kou (2017, Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics, in press) proposed a new method for the structure refinement of proteins. The new method allows information pooling from protein data bank. By utilizing the known structures in the protein data bank, our proposed method is able to leverage information from the known heterogeneous protein structures, resulting in significant improvement in protein structure refinement and prediction. Wong, Liu and Kou (2018, Annals of Applied Statistics, 12, 1628-1654) further extends the hierarchical method to three problems (a) improving structure predictions built from protein homology, (b) predicting reconstructed protein loop segments, and (c) assessing different energy functions for protein folding, and obtained results more accurate than what had been previously reported in the literature.

The grant helped the PI to translate the current and ongoing research for classroom teaching; simplified versions of our methods have been successfully applied in the lectures for both undergraduate and graduate students. The grant also helped support and train Ph. D. students to prepare for research career. Graduate students received rigorous training on hierarchical models, shrinkage estimation and model prediction. The projects they worked on contributed significantly to their Ph.D. research development and their career development.
